Izzie Ramirez
writer at NYU Local
Mar 30

Fast Food Low Down

The *correct* ranking of America’s favorite fast foods

As much as we all like to think we’re above fast food, we’re not. Plain and simple. It’s addicting and delicious as hell. However, some fast food meals are better than others.

In response to some serious allegations by a First We Feast ranking of fast food fries (who puts Chick-fil-A fries at #11?) and The Ringer’s “The Top 50 Fast Food Items In America,” which incorrectly has McDonald’s McGriddle at #42, this article aims to make reparations for these ill wills.

Buckle up.

FRIES

  1. McDonald’s

I’m sorry, but McDonald’s fries are SCIENTIFICALLY proven to be delicious. With its 19 ingredient recipe, McDonald’s fries are a work of delicately sliced art. The outside is always fried to a perfectly golden crisp while the inside retains the ideal amount of chewiness. It helps that the fries are never mealy in texture. These are the fries you tell yourself you’re going to stop eating on the drive home, but you end up eating not only yours but also your friend’s fries. It would be a sacrilegious disgrace to not put these beauties at number one.

2. Chick-fil-A

God bless Chick-fil-A’s waffle fries. They’re a fun shape. They go great with ketchup, barbecue sauce or Polynesian. They’re supposedly healthier due to being fried in refined peanut oil — which, by the way, I am so sorry if you’re allergic to peanuts. It must be hard never being able to eat one of America’s favorite fries.

3. Jack in the Box

Although the fast food chain has notoriously earned the name “Crack in the Box” for its lackluster burgers, their seasoned curly fries are anything but. The fries are substantial with a spicy kick. However, they’re not crispy, which makes it a big hit for those who are on Team Soggy Fries (whatever floats your boat, guys).

4. Popeyes

Much like Jack in the Box’s curly fries, Popeyes’ cajun fries’ seasoning is not limited to salt. No. According to rumor and copy cat recipes, these bad boys are lightly dusted with paprika and cayenne. But there are a few shortcomings: the seasoning isn’t always consistent — it can be bland at times (disappointing) or the fries are too thick (which ruins the crispy-to-mushy ratio).

5. Shake Shack

Three words: crinkle cut fries. Shake Shack fries are so famous among crinkle cut fanatics. In fact, one time Shake Shack tried to remove them because they were frozen from a manufacturer. They were the only thing on the menu that weren’t made in-house. Plus, the restaurant thought they could make a better fry. They were wrong. People were pissed. Eventually, the frozen fries came back, but with no artificial preservatives. As for the actual taste, they’re fine fries with a nice crunch — but certainly not revolutionary or different. Perhaps that’s why they’re so loved.

BURGERS

  1. Five Guys’ Bacon Cheeseburger

Five Guys — the East Coast burger chain— allows for maximum customization of your burger without ridicule, which is honestly pretty awesome. You can get it regular (two patties) or “little” (one patty). Then you get to choose the toppings. The go-to option is called “All the Way” and comes with lettuce, pickles, tomatoes, grilled onions, grilled mushrooms, ketchup, mayo and mustard. Not to mention, there’s other toppings on request like relish, jalapeños, A-1 sauce, etc. It’s a lot to handle. Personally, I’m a girl of simple tastes. My toppings of choice are tomatoes, grilled onions and barbecue sauce. Mix that with the bacon and you’re golden. As for the beef itself, it’s truly something else. It’s juicy without being crumbly. Hearty without being overwhelming. You’re definitely getting what you’re paying for. One bite and you’ll be like this guy:

Or like this guy:

2. Shake Shack’s Double ShackBurger

Shake Shack has the best bun. Period. It’s toasted in butter, but it’s never too slippery, squishy or sweet. It’s a bun with purpose. Toss in two beautifully seared and browned beef patties, melted American cheese, lettuce, tomato, and ShackSauce (a Thousand Island sauce similar to In-N-Out’s) and you’re good to go. You can’t customize it that much, but perhaps that’s a good thing. If it ain’t broke, don’t fix it.

3. In-N-Out’s Double Double

Speaking of In-N-Out, their version of a double cheeseburger is not as great as all Californians make it out to be. It could be the hype that kills the experience, which isn’t all that bad. Actually, the Double Double is pretty darn good. The Double Double gets its name because there are two slices of cheese AND two beef patties. Revolutionary. Usually, it comes with lettuce, onion, tomatoes and the famous In-N-Out sauce. The combination of all these ingredients, fresh ingredients I might add, makes for a tangy burger. The only downside is that there still isn’t enough meat. The patties are on the thin side and can be lackluster in texture.

4. McDonald’s Big Mac

What’s a burger list without the Big Mac? With its “special sauce,” the Big Mac is the less bougie version of the Double ShackBurger and Double Double. (Side note: for those who are curious, Big Mac sauce is made with mayo, relish, mustard, vinegar, garlic powder, onion powder and paprika. You can make it at home or you can find it at a grocery store near you one of these days). The toppings fall on the basic side, though. The Big Mac usually comes with pickles, lettuce, onions and cheese. But what sets it apart, besides the price, is the third bun. Yes, you read that right. A third bun. A sesame seed bun, no less. The Big Mac deserves to be on this list because of its iconic history, the daring third bun and the price. You can’t beat that.

5. Burger King’s Whopper

Have it your way, indeed. Burger King, like Five Guys, believes in the customer’s right to eat their burger how they want it. The Whopper’s quarter bound beef patty is alright. It tends to lean towards the dry side, depending on who is making the burger that day. Topping options include the usual: lettuce, onion, tomatoes (!!!), pickles, mayo and ketchup. An important thing to mention, the Whopper does not come with cheese. You have to ask for it. Points off for having to go through that nuisance. (Pro tip: order onion rings on the side and put a few in your burger. Trust me on this).

CHICKEN

  1. Chick-fil-A’s Spicy Chicken Sandwich

There are big moments in our lives where we remember exactly where we were. I remember where I was when the financial crash of 2008 happened. I remember where I was when Michael Jackson died. I remember where I was when Chick-fil-A released the Spicy Chicken Sandwich. My local Chick-fil-A rolled out the sandwich on June 5, 2010 and it changed my life for the better.

Before the Spicy Chicken Sandwich, the only items on the menu with a bit of kick were the Spicy Cool Wrap (now altered) and the chicken strips, which weren’t really spicy. The strips just had more seasoning than the nuggets did. Of course, my Mexican taste buds were here for the ride. I wanted my mouth to burn. Indeed, the Spicy Chicken Sandwich delivers; it packs the heat without being overbearing or unnoticeable.

The breading differs from the typical fried chicken breading made from buttermilk. Instead, the breading is soft and tender. The same could be said for the chicken breast itself. When you take that first bite, you know you’re eating real chicken. Not whatever some food scientist in Iowa concocted in his lab. The meat boasts a pleasant texture—chewy and juicy, but not mushy or crunchy. The Deluxe (AKA the way you should order this) comes with pepper jack cheese, lettuce, tomatoes and pickles. Ask for no lettuce—their lettuce tends to make the whole sandwich fall apart. Regardless of its (few) imperfections, the sandwich, as a whole, is enough to make you cry. Just ask my roommate.

2. Popeyes’ Spicy Chicken Tenders

I don’t know if it’s obvious, but I love spicy food. So this should come as no surprise. Before Chick-fil-A’s Spicy Chicken Sandwich, there was Popeyes fixing our cravings for spicy chicken. Popeyes has found the balance between the three things that define fried chicken: a) batter b) juiciness and c) seasoning. The batter is not soft like Chick-fil-A’s — it’s flaky, buttery and crispy. One bite will not break your teeth like some fried chicken will do. The crunchiness enhances the experience of the juiciness flooding into your mouth. Even though some pieces of the tenders are dark meat, it’s never dry. As for the seasoning, it’s the kind of hotness that builds up over time. You’re not going to be like, “I need a glass of milk” with Popeyes. The seasoning is smoky with a punch. A true success.

3. Kentucky Fried Chicken’s Original Recipe Chicken

KFC is iconic. In fact, it’s so iconic, the recipe with 11 spices is under lock and key. I’m pretty sure stealing the KFC Original Recipe is going to be the next National Treasure movie starring Nic Cage. Not to mention, when Colonel Sanders invented the pressure fryer — a cross between the pressure cooker and the deep fryer—he changed the game. He could now fry meat at a faster rate without wasting. The chicken itself is velvety and herby in flavor. You can also feed a whole family with a bucket of chicken and it’s not expensive to do so. Or you could get the Double Down, which is a sandwich with the chicken breasts as the bread stuffed with bacon, cheese and Colonel’s sauce. It’s a guaranteed heart attack.

4. Chick-fil-A’s Chicken Nuggets

These nuggets are a real crowd pleaser. The nuggets have a similar breading style to the Spicy Chicken Sandwich, but are savory and sweet. And unlike most nuggets (*cough* McDonald’s and Burger King *cough*), these nuggets are indeed chicken and boast the normal texture chicken should have. Shocker, I know. They’re also only white meat. This is the best no-bone, white-meat-only fast food nuggets you will find. Most important, however, is the ~magic~ effect these nuggets have on kids. If you’re ever babysitting a kid who is acting a little rowdy, give him a box of 6 pc. nuggets. That’ll pacify him real quick.

5. Burger King’s Chicken Fries

Honestly, these look more like mozzarella sticks or chicken tenders than they do fries, but Burger King’s Chicken Fries are such a blast. Rolled (?) into long cylinders of meat, these are a step up from the chain’s flavorless, mealy nuggets. Honorable mention for the amount of crunch and quirky packaging.

FAKE MEXICAN FOOD

  1. Taco Bell’s Crunchy Taco Supreme

I have so much love for this taco. Besides puppies and politics, the Crunchy Taco Supreme is probably the thing I tweet about the most. One time, instead of working on my Writing I essay, I explained to my friends why the meat-sour cream ratio makes the Crunchy Taco Supreme addictively delicious.

Another time, a friend texted me some great news. (Maybe I’ll consider studying abroad in Shanghai now?)

Another pal sent me this Snap over break. It reminded me of those very “edgy” indie films Tisch boys seem to make all the time.

I don’t know where I was, but apparently I was really craving Taco Bell.

It’s honestly absurd how many people I have bonded with over Taco Bell. Case and point:

It’s almost as if I’m obsessed with Taco Bell and its Crunchy Taco Supreme. Why? I have a few theories:

  • My mom ate Taco Bell when she was pregnant with me all the time.
  • The aforementioned sour cream-meat ratio. It optimizes the tang of the meat and distracts you from the fact that the beef is probably not beef at all. The cool temperature of the sour cream is reminiscent of a nice dip in the pool after a long day of being outside in the heat. Pair that off with a large Coca-Cola — excuse me, I mean Pepsi (c’mon, Taco Bell! Who drinks Pepsi?) — and you’ve reached the Garden of Eden.
  • The Crunchy Taco Supreme is not Mexican food. No fast food joint will give you the authentic Mexican cuisine experience. But what it is though is there for you. Taco Bell for you is there for you when no one else is. One time, I was driving back from a competition at 2 a.m. and I had a lung infection, an ear infection and was just given a steroid shot. Needless to say, Taco Bell comforted me in a way no other fast food chain ever will. Taco Bell is loyal. It will never leave you for a woman named Becky.
  • The Crunchy Taco Supreme is not limited to beef, sour cream, lettuce, tomatoes and cheese. It’s customizable. You can make it “fresco” style, which replaces the sour cream and cheese with pico de gallo, if you’re interested. You can add bacon, guacamole, rice. Is the plain shell not cutting it for you? Try the different varieties of Doritos shells. The list goes on and on.
  • Elevate your taco with their Verde, Mild, Hot or Fire hot sauces, decorated with cheeky jokes.
  • You can get a box of 12 tacos for $15. You can feed four people with that. Or just yourself if you’re really determined.

The Crunchy Taco Supreme is fast food at its finest. Just be sure to eat it within the first five minutes, or else it will get soggy.

2. Sonic’s Ched ‘R’ Peppers

Sonic’s Ched ‘R’ Peppers, deep fried jalapeños stuffed with gooey cheddar cheese, are a road trip staple. They’re not particularly spicy — I assume that the jalapeños are canned or are cooked with vinegar before they are fried — but, as always, it’s how the melty inside interacts with the crunchy and oily outside that makes the Ched ‘R’ Peppers something to reckon with and perfect for any viewing party. Watching your bracket unfold before your eyes with your friends? Get the family size order of these bad boys and enjoy the greasy, cheesy bliss.

3. Taco Bell’s Power Bowl

The Power Bowl is Taco Bell’s condensed version of a burrito bowl from Chipotle. It’s also better; it’s cheaper, more convenient and, surprisingly, also healthier! The caloric intake from a burrito bowl can range from 600 to 1200 calories whereas the Power Bowl is a solid 480 calories if you order it the way it comes. The Power Bowl has chicken, black beans, latin rice, lettuce, cheese, sour cream, pico de gallo and an avocado ranch sauce. The best part? You don’t have to ask for guac. It already comes with it.

4. Jack in the Box’s Chicken Fajita Pita

The Chicken Fajita Pita is the best thing on the Jack in the Box menu, hands down. It’s…healthy. GASP. I know, I know. With only 366 calories and a substantial serving of chicken, the Chicken Fajita Pita is filling and delicious. It doesn’t taste like you’re eating fast food. It’s something your roommate could make. Which means it can be bland at times, but there is a solution: the salsa. I’m not talking about the prepackaged taco sauce. I mean the little salsa that comes in a container on the side. The salsa is almost of Mexican restaurant quality, with chunky bits of tomato and onion. And it makes or breaks the pita. Do not forgo the salsa or you will be bored while eating the Chicken Fajita Pita. The salsa highlights the savoriness of the chicken and the creaminess of the cheese while adding a bit of spiciness. I repeat: do not forgo the salsa.

5. Jack in the Box’s Two Tacos for 99¢

These are actually terrible, but you can’t beat that price. Even if it means selling your soul a little.

BREAKFAST

  1. McDonald’s Bacon, Egg and Cheese McGriddle

If you were to look at the definition of science’s greatest invention, it would be the McGriddle — the perfect balance between savory (the bacon and the cheese) and sweet (the cakes and the maple syrup). It’s the best of both worlds.

2. Chick-fil-A’s Chicken Minis

Chicken Minis dive into the savory-sweet realm of breakfast foods like the McGriddle, except Minis are chicken nuggets wedged between rolls drizzled with a honey butter dressing. They’re mind-blowing, but you can only get servings of three or four and that’s never enough. If Chick-fil-A were to offer boxes of, say, six Minis or eight Minis…then we’d be talking.

3. Chick-fil-A’s Chicken, Egg and Cheese Bagel

What a hearty meal. The chicken breast is the same size as the one in regular chicken sandwich and the sunflower seed bagel is gigantic. If you eat this for breakfast, you probably won’t eat much for lunch.

4. McDonald’s Big Breakfast with Hotcakes

With hotcakes, sausage patties, biscuits, scrambled eggs AND hash browns, it’s no wonder why this dish is called the Big Breakfast. Why spend more at IHOP when you can get all that food for a low price at McDonald’s?

5. Whataburger’s Honey Butter Chicken Biscuit

Honey butter belongs on chicken. And biscuits.

DESSERT

  1. In-N-Out’s Chocolate Milkshake

You know when do something wild and you get a rush of adrenaline and you feel your mood instantly elevate? In-N-Out’s Chocolate Milkshake is the embodiment of that feeling.

2. Chick-fil-A’s Peach Milkshake

There are actually peach chunks in this thick, creamy milkshake! AMAZING. (It’s a shame this shake is seasonal, though).

3. McDonald’s Baked Apple Pie

Antonyms for the beautiful cinnamon-dusted and Hot Pocket-like, McDonald’s Baked Apple Pie include “dry,” “flavorless” and “undercooked.” Thank God the Baked Apple Pie is none of these things. As with everything they do, McDonald’s food scientists once again prove that we are not better than the desires of a five year old who does not understand that McDonald’s is bad for you.

4. Krispy Kreme’s Glazed Donut

The Glazed Donut is an ethereal creature — light, fluffy and delicately glazed. The best time to get one is when the “Hot Light” (the sign indicating fresh donuts are being made) is on.

5. Sonic’s Cherry Limeade

Although it’a technically not a dessert, Sonic’s Cherry Limeade — a wonderful marriage between cherry syrup and Sprite — is a must.

And there you have it. Have objections? Sound off in the comment section below or send me a Tweet.
